dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doll’s house is kept in BRIONY’s bedroom. At 13, she’ youngest of the family, an intense-looking child with a w temperament. Her room is meticulously tidy, with model an arranged with military precision, all facing in the same direction, two by two, as if queuing for the Ark. BRIONY is typing out a version of her just-completed firs a battered copy of the Oxford English Dictionary open on desk. As the CAMERA arrives at her manuscript, she is typ with a confident flourish, the words THE END. Having done she leans forward to pull the page from the typewriter an it to a small pile (the play is no more than 8 pages) of manuscript, the cover page of which reads THE TRIALS OF A by Briony Tallis. It’s still early in the morning, but th of sweat BRIONY brushes from her forehead tell us that th is already exceptionally hot. INT. LANDING, STAIRCASE AND HALLWAY. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding her manuscript, BRIONY hurries along the landing, door opening on to a spare bedroom. Inside, a HOUSEMAID i singing as she makes up twin beds. BRIONY descends the se staircase, which leads to a black-and-white tiled hallway doesn’t even glance into the library, a vast, gloomy room glimpsed through its open door, but turns to move towards back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIONY glances into the empty dining room and passes thro scullery into the huge old kitchen, where GRACE TURNER, t housekeeper, sits at one end of the kitchen table polishi silver, while BETTY, the cook, is supervising two or thre KITCHEN-MAIDS, who are peeling mounds of potatoes, scouri trays, etc.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I’ve finished my play!

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Well done, dear.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Have you seen Mummy?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I expect she’ll be in the drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I hope you're not going to be getting under our feet today, Miss Briony, we've got a dinner for ten to prepare. BRIONY’s already on her way out of the room, not listenin INT. HALLWAY. DAY. BRIONY hurries back down the hall, reaches the drawing ro and is about to enter when she sees ROBBIE TURNER, an imp looking young man of 24 in working clothes, outside an op leading to the formal gardens. He’s putting on a pair of gardening boots.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hello pal. I hear you’re putting on a play.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Who told you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Jungle drums.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Will you come and see it?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure that would be quite...  He breaks off, quickly finds another tack and stands.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you let me read it? You used to make me beautiful bound copies of all your stories.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I still want you to come.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Let’s see. BRIONY enters the drawing room. Inside the morning news p the wireless.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Mummy, I need you! She closes the door behind her. INT. DRAWING ROOM. DAY. The drawing room is an enormous corner room looking out o terrace. EMILY TALLIS, BRIONY’s mother, a slightly faded with pale skin and raw nerves, finishes reading BRIONY’s manuscript. The radio has been turned off. BRIONY hovers her, anxious and excited. EMILY looks up and smiles warml BRIONY.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Stupendous! It’s stupendous, darling! Your first play!

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Do you think Leon will like it?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Well of course he will. ‘The Trials of Arabella’ by Briony Tallis. EXT. TALLIS HOUSE. GARDENS. DAY. It’s no later than 10am, but the sun is already high and down on the monumental facade of the Tallis house, recogn from its miniature version seen earlier. Lying on one of rolling lawns is CECILIA TALLIS, BRIONY’s sister, a beaut restless-looking girl of 23, who is making a desultory at to read a fat edition of Richardson’s Clarissa. She turns page to re-read something, then sighs, rolls on to her ba shuts her eyes against the sun. BRIONY is lying a few fee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cee?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: What do you think it would feel like to be someone else?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Cooler, I should hope. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I’m worried about the play.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I’m sure it’s a masterpiece.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: But we only have the afternoon to rehearse. What if the twins can’t act?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: You have to be nice to them. Think how you'd feel if your mother had run off with Mr. What’s-His-Name who reads the news on the wireless.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should have written Leon a story. If you write a story, you only have to say the word ‘castle’ and you can see the towers and the woods and the village below... But in a play it’s... it all depends on other people.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Mm. BRIONY rolls over. Some way off, ROBBIE TURNER pushes a wheelbarrow up to a flower bed and parks it.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Cee?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don’t you talk to Robbie any more?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I do. We just move in different circles, that’s all. Down by the flower bed, ROBBIE glances across at CECILIA BRIONY. But he’s very focused on his immediate task which planting of a row of cuttings from the greenhouse. He wip sweat off his forehead and begins to dig with a trowel. INT. NURSERY. DAY. Rehearsals are taking place in a now disused room on the floor, the former nursery, occupying the front corner of house. BRIONY has wedged herself into an old high chair a looks down at her red-headed cousins: LOLA QUINCEY, 15, a twin 9 year-old brothers, PIERROT and JACKSON. They’re al clutching handwritten copies of BRIONY’s play.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Do we have to do a play?

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: Why do we have to?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: It’s to celebrate my brother Leon’s visit.

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: I hate plays.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: So do I.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: How can you hate plays?

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: It’s just showing off. LOLA crosses her legs, revealing an ankle bracelet above sandals, and a set of brightly painted toenails; she spea quite calmly.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: You'll be in this play or you'll get a clout and I’1l tell the Parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not allowed to clout us.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: We're guests in this house and what did the Parents say we were to make ourselves? Well? Pierrot?

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: Amenable.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Jackson?

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Amenable.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Amenable, that’s right. She turns graciously to BRIONY.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Now, Briony, what’s your play about?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: It’s about how... love is all very well, but you have to be sensible. LOLA frowns, dubious.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I suppose you’re going to be Arabella.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Well... Not necessarily. She’s been surprised into this, but LOLA takes immediate ruthless advantage.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: In that case, do you mind if I play her?

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Lola was in the school play.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Do say yes, it’d be the first decent thing to happen to me in months. BRIONY can’t see any way to get out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... all right.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I suppose we should start by reading it...

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: If you're going to be Arabella, then I’ll be the director, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Sorr-ee!

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I’m going to do the prologue. She looks down and begins reading.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Prologue. This is the tale of spontaneous Arabella Who ran away with an extrinsic fellow. It grieved her parents to see their first born Evanesce from her home to go to Eastbourne... The door opens; BRIONY breaks off and looks up to see DAN HARDMAN, the seventeen year-old spotty son of the head ga standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just thought I'd watch.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Rehearsals are private, I’m afraid. You can see the play this evening.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’1l have to work then.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sorry, Danny. DANNY reluctantly prises himself away, closing the door b him. BRIONY turns back to the OTHERS.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Can we have a swim now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yes!

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: There’s no time!

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: Cecilia will let us. Before BRIONY can respond, the TWINS are charging towards door, pretending to fire guns at one another and shouting CECILIA.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I’m sure a half-hour break would do us all good. LOLA saunters casually after the twins, leaving BRIONY al She sits on the floor, her back up against the wall, fann herself with her script, her expression morose. A wasp is buzzing irritatingly, trapped between two panes of the op window. BRIONY gets up and goes over to liberate it. She’ to lower the sash, when something outside catches her att Below, to one side of the house, is a terrace, dominated monumental fountain. Beside the fountain are ROBBIE and C glaring at each other. As BRIONY watches, ROBBIE stretches out a hand and says something, as if issuing a command. In response, although expression is mutinous, CECILIA immediately kicks off her unbuttons and removes her blouse and strips off her skirt that she’s standing before ROBBIE in her underwear. BRIONY gasps and steps back from the window. The wasp buz frantically. When she returns, ROBBIE is standing motionless by the fo and CECILIA has disappeared. Then, suddenly, the surface water breaks and CECILIA emerges from the fountain. She p her clothes, turns her back on ROBBIE and pulls them on t still dripping body. Then she bends and rises again, this holding a previously invisible vase of flowers, and strid back towards the house. ROBBIE, left by the fountain, rea out a hand and lays it on the surface of the water. BRIONY lowers the sash with a bang, liberating the wasp. EXT. WOODS. DAY. CUT BACK IN TIME. CECILIA, with an armful of wild flowers, runs through th enjoying the sheer exhilaration of movement. There isn’t in the sky. EXT./INT. NURSERY. DAY. CLOSE on BRIONY, seen through the window,staring out. EXT. WOODS. DAY. CUT BACK IN TIME. CECILIA runs on through the woods. INT. HALLWAY. DAY. CECILIA crosses the hall, as the TWINS come clattering an shouting down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Can we go for a swim please, Cecilia?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I don’t see why not, as long as you don’t go near the deep end. And the TWINS rush away as CECILIA steps into the drawing INT./EXT. DRAWING-ROOM. DAY. CECILIA crosses to the window. Outside, ROBBIE is standin rolling himself a cigarette. CECILIA goes over to a cherry-wood table, where there’s a 18th-century Meissen vase. She drops the flowers untidily it and pulls out a crushed packet of cigarettes, which tu to be empty. She glances back out of the window, picks up vase, checks her reflection in the mirror and strides out towards the terrace. EXT. TERRACE. DAY. CECILIA speaks a little sharply, startling ROBBIE.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Can you do me one of your Bolshevik roll-ups?  10. She doesn’t stop; and he follows her, making the cigarett she heads across the lawn towards the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Beautiful day.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I suppose so. Too hot for me. They move on in silence.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: How are you enjoying your book?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It gets better.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I'd rather read Fielding any day. Much more... passionate. CECILIA suddenly feels awkward and hastens to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Leon’s coming down today, did you know?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I’d heard a rumour.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: He’s bringing a friend with him. This Paul Marshall. The chocolate millionaire.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Are the flowers for him?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Why shouldn't they be? Leon says he’s very charming. They reach the fountain: CECILIA puts the vase down on th step leading up to it. ROBBIE hands her the cigarette and it. They obviously know one another very well; yet there’ definite, perceptible constraint between them. There’s mo than a hint of accusation in what CECILIA says next.  11.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: The Old Man telephoned last night. He says you’re planning to be a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I’m thinking about it, yes.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Another six years of student life?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: How else do you become a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: You could get a Fellowship now, couldn’t you? With your First.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: But I don’t want to teach... He breaks off, looks away for a moment; then turns back t

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I said I’d pay your father back.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: That’s not what I meant at all. There’s an edge of real hostility in her voice. She puts cigarette between her lips and bends to pick up the vase, preparing to dunk it in the fountain, having first taken flowers and laid them on the step.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Let me do that.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I’m all right, thanks. But ROBBIE persists, reaching for the vase.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You take the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I’m all right! He gets hold of the vase, just as CECILIA turns away; and the crisp sound of a dry twig snapping, two triangular se of the rim of the vase detach themselves in his hands. In  12. shock, he lets them go; and they drop into the fountain a slowly, spiralling to the bottom, almost three feet down. CECILIA looks at him, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: You idiot! You realise this is probably the most valuable thing we own.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Not any more, it isn’t. The hint of truculence in his voice serves to agitate CEC even more. She sets the vase down. Then straightens up, a that ROBBIE has begun to unbutton his shirt. She takes a towards him, then, confusedly, a step back. ROBBIE, afrai going to step on the vase, throws out a restraining hand, gesture so abrupt as to seem peremptory.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Careful! CECILIA’s response is to kick off her shoes and, in front ROBBIE’s transfixed gaze, to strip down to her underwear. she steps over the lip of the fountain and lowers herself it. She gasps at the unexpectedly cold water, but doesn’t hes to plunge her face beneath the surface. ROBBIE, watches, unable to look away, his expression a qu mixture of fear and longing. CECILIA’S hair fantails out the surface of the water. UNDERWATER. DAY. CECILIA reaches down to the bottom of the basin and caref retrieves the two triangular shards of porcelain. EXT. TERRACE. DAY. CECILIA lays the two pieces of pottery down by the vase a with her back to ROBBIE, scrambles back into her clothes. she gathers up her sandals, tucks them under her arm, pic the pottery fragments and puts them in her skirt pocket, up the vase of flowers and marches back towards the house ROBBIE stands there, watching her go. Then he reaches out and lays it on the surface of the water, as if to calm it  13. EXT./INT. NURSERY. DAY. BRIONY, seen through the window, closes it and stays wher is for a moment, staring out. Then she turns back into th and crosses it, grabbing up her notebook. EXT. PERGOLA. DAY. BRIONY strides through the rose-covered pergola, moving a from the house. EXT. TALLIS HOUSE DRIVE. DAY. A cream-coloured Rolls-Royce makes its stately way up the INT./EXT. CECILIA’S BEDROOM. DAY. CECILIA’s room is heroically untidy. The bed is unmade, t floor is littered with papers, clothes, and open books, t ashtrays are overflowing and the dressing-table is a disa area. CECILIA herself sits, painting her toenails, when s hears the SOUND of the approaching motor. She crosses to window gingerly, so as not to ruin her nail polish. In the distance she sees ROBBIE striding across the lawns way down to the lodge, where he lives with his mother. Th Royce slows and stops alongside ROBBIE and the passenger out to speak to him. CECILIA frowns in obvious annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: No need to encourage him. INT. HALLWAY. DAY. The two young men, LEON TALLIS, 25, and his friend PAUL MARSHALL, 28, surge into the house, followed by DANNY HAR struggling with their suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Cee! Mother! He turns to DANNY.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Where is everyone, Danny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunno, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: I’m gasping for a drink. 14. He steps into the drawing room. DANNY, still with the lug follows confusedly. INT. DRAWING ROOM. DAY. LEON is moving over to the drinks table.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Will you have one?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Rather.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Whisky?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Please. As LEON fixes the drinks, CECILIA bursts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Leon! LEON takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Here she is!

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Oh, I’ve missed you. I’ve been going completely doolally up here. LEON turns to include MARSHALL.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: This is my sister, Cecilia; Paul Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I’ve heard an awful lot about you.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Likewise.  15.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Where are we putting him? CECILIA turns to DANNY.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: In the blue room. DANNY starts off up the stairs, then stops, looking gorml

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Mother's lying down, she’s got one of her migraines.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Not surprised, this heat. CECILIA looks up at DANNY, somewhat irritated.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: The big room next to the nursery. DANNY sets off, grunting with effort.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Is the Old Man staying in town?

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Looks like it. There’s some sort of rush on at the Ministry. INT. EMILY TALLIS‘S BEDROOM. DAY. EMILY is on her bed in her darkened room, propped up agai pillows, her eyes protected by an eyeshade, cooled by an electric fan that whirs on her bedside table. From the nursery comes the regular thud of a bouncing rub ball. EMILY sighs and pushes up her eyeshade. INT. NURSERY. DAY. The TWINS are sitting in their still wet bathing suits, b a rubber ball against the wall. LOLA lies on the couch, flicking through a fashion magazi

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: So aren't we doing the play?  16.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Don’t ask me.

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: I don’t like it here. EXT. LAKE. DAY. On the lake floats a white pontoon. CECILIA is wearing a one-piece swimsuit and nursing a glass of punch. MARSHALL LEON are also in bathing suits. We’re looking at CECILIA, on the diving board in the blinding heat, as MARSHALL’s d voice nibbles at the edge of her attention.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: And currently our main challenge is whether or not to launch the new Amo bar, the Army Amo. You see, Pass the Amo! CECILIA turns her head to look at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: My source at the Ministry of Defence - I used to clean his shoes at Harrow, so he’s very reliable - assures me we've a good chance of getting the Amo bar included in the standard-issue ration pack. Which means I’d have to open at least three more factories, more if they bring in conscription, which I’d say is bound to happen if Herr Hitler doesn’t pipe down - and he’s about as likely to do that as buy shares in Marks and Spencers, wouldn't you agree? CECILIA’s been making a valiant effort to seem interested she takes a sip of her punch.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: This isn’t very good.  17.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I make a cocktail with rum, crushed ice, and melted dark chocolate. Absolutely scrumptious! CECILIA manages to catch LEON’s eye and make a discreet v face; LEON is obliged to rise to his feet to conceal an irresistible burst of silent laughter. To recover, he tur to speak to CECILIA.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Guess who we met on the way in?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: I told him to join us tonight.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Leon! You didn’t!

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: (to Marshall) So Robbie the Housekeeper’s son, whose father did a bunk twenty years ago, gets a scholarship to the local grammar and the Old Man puts him through Cambridge; goes up at the same time as Cee and for three years she hardly speaks to him! She wouldn’t let him within a mile of her Roedean chums.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Anyone got a cigarette? MARSHALL produces a gold case, brings it over to CECILIA lights the cigarette she’s taken.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Don’t know what the hell he’s doing these days, messing about in flower beds... CECILIA is standing on the diving board now.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact he’s planning on doing a medical degree.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: And the Old Man said yes to that?  18.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Look, I think you ought to go down to the lodge and ask him not to come.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Why? Has something happened between you?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Oh, for God's sake. CECILIA dives into the lake. UNDERWATER. DAY. CECILIA swims by, powerful underwater breast-stroke. INT. BATHROOM IN THE LODGE. DAY. ROBBIE surfaces in his bath: he settles back, brooding, l up at a skylight, a small pane of glass directly above hi square of bright blue sky, through which flies an RAF pla INT. NURSERY. DAY. LOLA, PIERROT and JACKSON are hanging about aimlessly, al at a loss as to what to do.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: When can we go home?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: We can’t go home: it’s a divorce!

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: How dare you say that?

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: Well, it’s true. LOLA grabs PIERROT by the shoulders and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: You will never ever use that word again. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIERROT nods miserably. Eventually, JACKSON breaks the si  19.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Now what are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m always asking myself that. They’re all startled by PAUL MARSHALL’s sudden appearance doorway. He advances into the room, hand extended.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: My name’s Paul Marshall. And you must be the cousins from the north. What are your names? They tell him, as he shakes hands with them.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What marvellous names.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Do you know our parents?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve read about them in the paper. This causes consternation, from which LOLA is the first t recover.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: What exactly have you read about them? MARSHALL realizes it may be time to back-pedal.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know. Usual sort of nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I’1l thank you not to talk about this in front of the children. MARSHALL turns to the TWINS and speaks with glutinous sol

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Your parents are absolutely wonderful people, that’s quite clear and they love you and think about you all the time. LOLA’s expression changes; he’s successfully appeased her follows swiftly through with a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jolly nice slacks. LOLA smooths them down, visibly pleased.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: We went up to see a show and got them at Liberty’s.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What was the show?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Hamlet.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Ah, yes: to be or not to be.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I like your shoes. MARSHALL tilts his brown and white co-respondent shoes, self-satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Ducker’s in the Turl. They make a... wooden thing shaped like your foot and keep it for ever.

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: I’m starving, when’s dinner?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I might be able to help you out, if you can guess what I do for a living.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: You've got a chocolate factory.

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: Everyone knows that.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Ah, so it wasn’t a guess. 20. serenely He takes a slab of something wrapped in greaseproof paper his pocket and unwraps it to reveal a shell of khaki suga he taps with his fingernail.  21.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: There’1l be one of these provided in every kitbag of every soldier in the British Army. Sugar casing so it won’t melt.

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: Why should they get free sweets?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Because they'll be fighting for their country.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: Our Daddy says there isn’t going to be a war.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Your Daddy is wrong. He’s snapped at the boy, and now smiles wolfishly in an a to make amends.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: We're calling it the Army Amo.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Amo amas amat.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Top marks.

dialogues.speaker: PIERROT
dialogues.text: It’s boring how everything ends in 0. Polo and Aero.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: And Oxo and Brillo.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Sounds as if you don’t want it then. I shall have to give it to your sister. Which he does. She takes it, smiling triumphantly at the disappointed TWINS. She glances flirtatiously at MARSHALL watches with frank interest as she wraps her lips around of the bar. His voice is soft and breathy.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Bite it. You have to bite it.  22. EXT. GROTTO. DAY. Beyond the formal lawns at the bottom of the garden is an crumbling grotto. This is BRIONY’s place: she sits in the scribbling furiously in her notebook.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Princess was aware of his remorseless wickedness, but that made it no easier to overcome the voluminous love she felt for Sir Romulus...The Princess knew instinctively that the one with red hair was not to be trusted...As his young ward dived into the depths of the lake in search of the enchanted chalice, Sir Romulus twirled his luxuriant moustache...Sir Romulus rode north with his two companions, drawing ever closer to an effulgent sea...So heroic in manner he appeared, so valiant in word, no one could guess at the darkness lurking in the black heart of Sir Romulus Turnbull: he was the most dangerous man in the world. INT. ROBBIE’S STUDY/BEDROOM IN THE LODGE. DAY. ROBBIE sits at his typewriter, pensive. His tiny room is full of books; open on his desk is a copy of Grays Anatom reads back what he’s just written.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Dear Cecilia, I thought I should write to apologize for my clumsy and inconsiderate behaviour... He sighs, pulls the paper out of the typewriter, crumples and throws it in the waste-paper basket, where it joins o rejected drafts. INT. CECILIA’S BEDROOM. DAY. CECILIA is studying herself in the full-length mirror. Sh wearing a black dress and a jet necklace. With a profound sigh, she shakes her head and lets the dr fall to the floor.  23. On SOUND: the final duet of Act 1 of La Boheme. INT. ROBBIE'S STUDY/BEDROOM. DAY. The music is on ROBBIE’S gramophone. He leans back, wrenc the paper out of the typewriter, again, crumpling it and throwing it in the waste-paper basket. A series of JUMP CUTS: ROBBIE moves over to the gramophon stands a moment listening to the climax of the duet, pick the arm and moves the needle back to replay the high note paces his small room. He feeds another sheet of paper int typewriter, stubs out his cigarette, pulls the sheet out typewriter and starts again. Decisively, he begins to typ As he types, the words appear on the paper: “In my dreams your cunt, your sweet wet cunt. In my thoughts I make lov you all day long. Robbie.” ROBBIE sits back with a small gasp and laughs; he’s surpr himself. Then he pulls the page out of the typewriter, se down on Gray’s Anatomy, pushes the typewriter aside and r for some notepaper and a fountain pen. After a pause for reflection, he unscrews the pen and starts writing. He writes: “Dear Cecilia...”

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. you'd be forgiven for thinking me mad-the way I acted this afternoon. INT. CECILIA'S BEDROOM. DAY. CECILIA is now wearing a green halter-neck evening gown a jet necklace has been replaced with a rope of pearls. A c of other dresses lie on the floor beside the rejected bla dress.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The truth is, I feel rather light- headed and foolish in your presence, Cee, and I don’t think I can blame the heat. Will you forgive me? Robbie. CECILIA fixes on a diamond hair-clip, contemplates her reflection for a moment, this time with satisfaction and the room.  24. INT. STAIRS/FRONT ROOM. LODGE. DAY. ROBBIE comes downstairs in a vest, carrying a shoe brush pair of black brogues. His mother, GRACE TURNER, whom we' already encountered in the Tallis kitchen, is sitting in front room with her eyes closed, her feet up and her slip dangling from her toes. ROBBIE spreads out a double page Daily Sketch, before sitting to polish his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Off out, then?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yes; Leon asked me to join them for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: So that’s why I’ve been polishing the silver all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I’1l think of you when I see my face in the spoon. He stands up. GRACE watches him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You’re not a bit like your father. Not in any way.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: That’s because I’m all yours. ROBBIE kisses his mother’s forehead.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I‘ll be late.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Your shirts are hanging upstairs. ROBBIE starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Son?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Nothing.  25. INT. ROBBIE'S STUDY/BEDROOM. DUSK. ROBBIE, rushing now, does up the front of his shirt and a same time finds an envelope, folds his letter, looks for cigarette case, puts the letter in the envelope and seals puts his jacket on, tests his lighter three times and lea room. EXT. LODGE & PARK. DUSK. ROBBIE leaves the bungalow, impeccable in his evening dre envelope in his hand and a spring in his step; he looks f the world like a young man with a glorious future. EXT. DRIVEWAY. DUSK. ROBBIE walks down the drive towards the Tallis house, his still in his hand. He comes to a monumental bridge that c a small stream. Below he sees a figure at the water’s edg slashing at nettles with a hazel switch.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Briony? Is that you? BRIONY turns, obviously startled and straightens her hair

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Are you all right? BRIONY nods, her face flushing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Do you think you could do me a favour? BRIONY scrambles up the slope to join ROBBIE.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Could you run ahead and give this to Cee? I'd feel a bit of a fool handing it over myself.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: All right. She takes the envelope from him, turns and runs off witho another word. He starts to roll himself a cigarette. ROBBIE watches her go, leaving the drive to take a short across the grass, running all the way.  26. Suddenly ROBBIE gasps, as if punched in the solar plexus, lets drop the makings of the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Briony. EXT. GARDENS. DUSK. But BRIONY is out of earshot, running across the gardens, clutching the envelope. INT. ROBBIE’S STUDY/BEDROOM. DAY. CUT BACK IN TIME. Again ROBBIE tests his lighter three times and leaves the But this time the CAMERA PANS back to ROBBIE’s desk and m on the hand-written letter, still lying on his copy of Gr Anatomy. EXT. DRIVEWAY. DUSK. ROBBIE, panicked now, cups his hands around his mouth and at the top of his voice:

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Briony! INT. HALLWAY. DUSK. BRIONY runs into the hall and stands for a moment, alone. impulsively, she rips open the letter, stuffs the envelop her pocket and reads. The SOUND of a typewriter, builds to: INT. ROBBIE'S STUDY/BEDROOM. DAY. The hammers of ROBBIE’S typewriter in extreme close-up, c down with the word: C-U-N-T INT. HALLWAY. DUSK. WIDE on BRIONY, a tiny figure isolated in the vast hall, transfixed by what she’s just read.  27. INT. DRAWING ROOM. DUSK. CECILIA and LEON, both holding gin-and-tonics, sit in a w seat overlooking the gardens.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I suppose he’s what you might call eligible.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Rather!

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: He certainly seems to think he’s the cat's pyjamas. Which is odd, considering he has pubic hair growing out of his ears. LEON snorts with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I imagine he’d give you a lot of very noisy boneheaded sons.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: He’s quite a good egg, actually.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: You say that about everyone. LEON’S face lights up as BRIONY bursts into the room; he into his Arthur Askey impersonation.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Rummy, if it ain’t my little sis! BRIONY thrusts the letter into CECILIA’s hand without a w flings herself into LEON’S embrace.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I wrote a play, Leon. I wanted to do a play for you, The Trials of Arabella. CLOSE on CECILIA as she unfolds the letter and reads. She blushes hotly, looks up to make sure her shock has not be observed and bows her head to read it again.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: There’s still time, doesn’t have to be this evening.  28.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: No, it’s impossible!

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Briony? BRIONY completely ignores CECILIA, pretending to hang on every word.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Tell you what, I’m good at voices and you're even better. We’1l read it out after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Briony, did you read this letter?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes, let’s, that’s a wonderful idea!

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Briony... CECILIA’s about to speak, but she’s interrupted by the su appearance of PAUL MARSHALL, who’s carrying a silver tray which stand five cocktail glasses containing a sludgy bro liquid. He has a faint scratch running down his right che

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Here we are, my chocktail; I insist you try it. BRIONY tries to take advantage of this to slip out of the but CECILIA grabs hold of her arm and hisses at her.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Wasn‘t there an envelope? BRIONY wriggles free and hurries out of the room. INT. BRIONY’S BEDROOM. DUSK. BRIONY, not yet changed, paces restlessly up and down, tr make sense of the events of the evening. There’s a light the door and she looks up, very surprised to see LOLA.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I come in? Before BRIONY can answer, LOLA comes in and perches on th of the bed; her expression is tragic. She’s dressed for d and wearing make-up and lipstick.  29.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I’ve had the most appalling evening. The twins have been torturing me. Look. She pulls up a sleeve to reveal a blue bruise on her uppe

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: How awful! As she speaks she notices LOLA’s wrist is blotched and so looking; she reaches out to take it.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Chinese burns?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: But why? LOLA is beginning to weep softly, in the presence of BRIO obvious sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: They want to go home. They think it’s me keeping them here.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Lola, can I tell you something? Something really terrible?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Yes, please.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: What’s the worst word you can possibly imagine? EXT. LAWN/TERRACE. DUSK. ROBBIE approaches the towering bulk of the house, draggin feet. He looks up at the lighted windows and comes to a h outside the front door, not at all sure he can bring hims proceed. Finally, he takes a deep breath and tugs at the pull.  INT. BRIONY’S BEDROOM. DUSK. LOLA seems to have made a complete recovery. She’s starin BRIONY in undisguised fascination.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: He’s a sex-maniac! BRIONY nods seriously, struggling to find the correct mat response.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: What’s Cecilia going to do? From below, a ring on the doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: You ought to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Do you think so?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: He said he thought about it ‘all day long.’ All you need do is show them the letter.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: You won’t tell anyone, will you? Promise.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I promise.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: If he found out, there’s no knowing what he might do.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: You’re right.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: You'd better tidy your face. I’ve still got to change. LOLA goes to the door, turns back in the doorway.  31.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Thanks, Briony, you’re a brick. She leaves the room. INT. STAIRCASE AND HALLWAY. NIGHT. BRIONY, now changed for dinner, crosses the landing and s down the last section of staircase leading to the hall. A reaches the bottom step, she notices a diamond hair-clip in front of the door to the library. She crosses to the h clip and picks it up. A moment later she hears a low moan recognizably CECILIA’S voice, coming from behind the door INT. LIBRARY. NIGHT. BRIONY opens the door quietly and stands, framed in the d peering apprehensively in. The library is cavernous and dark, lined with floor-to-ce bookshelves. The only light comes from a desk lamp that p directly into BRIONY’s eyes. Silence. BRIONY takes a tent couple of steps into the room. As she does so, there’s a from the far corner.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (whispering) Someone’s come in. BRIONY edges closer and suddenly, revealed in the corner, against the bookshelves, are ROBBIE and CECILIA. ROBBIE, one of CECILIA’s wrists pinned against the wall, appears attacking CECILIA, while CECILIA has a hand round his hea gripping a handful of hair. BRIONY, bewildered, stops by the desk.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Cecilia? SOUND of a doorbell. EXT. TALLIS HOUSE. DUSK. CUT BACK IN TIME. CLOSE on ROBBIE’S hand, tugging at the bell-pull. When the door opens, it’s CECILIA, the folded letter in h hand.  32.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Briony read it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh God. I’m so sorry. It was the wrong version.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No one was ever meant to...

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: No. INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT. CECILIA turns away and moves briskly towards the library. ROBBIE, after a second’s hesitation, follows her, almost stepping on the hair-clip which has dropped from her hair INT. LIBRARY. NIGHT. It’s dark in the library. ROBBIE waits in the doorway, until CECILIA has switched o desk-lamp; then he closes the door behind him and advance tentatively into the room. CECILIA crosses almost the ful of the room, before turning to face him.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: What was in the version I was meant to read?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, it was more formal, it was less...

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Anatomical?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yes. CECILIA doesn’t know whether to laugh or cry. ROBBIE begi inch towards her as she begins to back gradually into a d corner, until she’s up against the bookshelves.  33.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: It’s been there for weeks and then this morning by the fountain... I’ve never done anything like that before and I was so angry with you, and with myself. I thought if you went away to medical school, I’d be happy. I don’t know how I could have been so ignorant about myself. So stupid. Tears well in her eyes. He’s moving closer and closer.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: You do know what I’m talking about, don’t you? You knew before I did.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Why are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Don’t you know?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yes, I know exactly. He reaches out and draws her to him, until their faces ar inches apart. He kisses her briefly and pulls back; then look at each other and kiss again, this time a long, pass and breathless kiss, that draws from CECILIA a falling, s sound. He pushes her back into the corner and she starts at his shirt, pulling at his waistband. He buries his fac her breasts and she drags his head up by the hair and bit lip. She links her hands around his neck. He reaches down her dress and into her underwear. She kicks off her shoes raises one of her feet on to the lowest shelf. He undoes buttons, lifts her dress and enters her. She turns her he sharply, biting her lip. They stop moving and slowly turn look into each other’s eyes. Then, after a long, still pa they whisper to one another, barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Cecilia.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I love you.  34. She gasps as he starts moving again, crushing her against creaking shelves. He takes her wrist and holds it back ag the wall. The door opens. CECILIA and ROBBIE freeze.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: (whispering) Someone’s come in.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Cecilia? CECILIA doesn’t answer. ROBBIE steps back from CECILIA an begins adjusting his clothes, keeping his back to BRIONY. CECILIA tidies herself up, steps out from behind ROBBIE a pushes past BRIONY without a word. BRIONY watches her lea room, at a loss, then turns back, startled, as she senses turning towards her. She takes a step back, frightened; b merely fumbles with his bow-tie and, staring coldly past leaves the room. INT. DINING ROOM. NIGHT. BRIONY enters the dining room to find ROBBIE holding CECI chair for her to sit. Also around the table are LEON, MAR LOLA and, at the top of the table, EMILY. DANNY HARDMAN i rather sloppily pouring wine for LEON, whilst leering acr table at LOLA.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: In Charlotte Street last week, people were sitting out having dinner on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: It was always the view of my parents that hot weather encouraged loose morals. In high summer my sister and I were never allowed out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: What do you say, Cee? Does the hot weather make you behave badly? CECILIA flushes red, taken by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Good heavens, you’re blushing.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: It’s just hot in here, that’s all.  35.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Lola, wipe that lipstick off. You’re far too young.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: What about you, Briony? What sins have you committed today? BRIONY, now seated, looks across at him indignantly.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I've done nothing wrong. She turns to look meaningfully at ROBBIE and CECILIA. Mea EMILY speaks to LOLA,

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Have you seen the twins recently?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Er...no. Following some nervous impulse, ROBBIE suddenly finds him joining in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: They didn’t look very happy last time I saw them, poor little chaps.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: You know nothing about it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I can’t imagine what’s got into you, Briony. I’ve never known you be so rude. CECILIA dabs her lip with a napkin to find a tiny spot of

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Well, they’re not poor little chaps: just look what they did to Lola!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Jackson and Pierrot. Bruised her arm, gave her Chinese burns.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: She’s quite right, I’m afraid, I had to pull them off her.  36. He indicates the scratch on his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: That’s how I got my war wound.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: The twins did that? Lola? LOLA doesn’t reply.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: It all turned into a bit of a wrestle. Still, no harm done, eh, Lola?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Would you go and find these boys please, Briony? Tell them dinner’s ready and where are their manners.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Why do I have to go?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Briony, you'll do as you're told or you'll go straight to your room. BRIONY rises from the table, her expression mutinous; EMI turns to inspect LOLA’s arm. Under the table, CECILIA rea for ROBBIE’s hand. INT. TWINS’ ROOM. NIGHT. BRIONY switches the light on and is surprised to find the empty. There’s a large ragged piece of paper on one of th As BRIONY moves towards it, she sees it’s headed in big r capitals: TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN. She reaches for it. INT. STAIRCASE AND HALLWAY. NIGHT. BRIONY comes flying down the stairs, the piece of paper i hand. INT. DINING ROOM. NIGHT. All heads turn as BRIONY flings open the door. CECILIA le of ROBBIE’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: It’s a letter!  37. CECILIA immediately panics.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Give it here. Then she sees what’s in BRIONY’S hand and relaxes; BRIONY meanwhile, is advancing towards the head of the table.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: They’ve run away.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Who has?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: The twins. BRIONY reads from the piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: “We are going to run away because Lola is so horrid to us and we want to go home. Also there wasn’t a play.” She hands the sheet of paper to EMILY. LOLA has gone pale

dialogues.speaker: MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Not to worry, we'll send out some search parties, they can’t have gone far.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Cee, you come with me. CECILIA manages to catch ROBBIE’s eye and half-shrugs, as say it can’t be helped. EXT/INT. TERRACE/DRAWING ROOM. NIGHT. BRIONY comes out on to the terrace; she hesitates a momen then moves off into the darkness. WIDE SHOT: the house with torch beams fanning out across grounds. VOICES calling out the twins’ names. EXT. LAKE. NIGHT. BRIONY crosses the small bridge that crosses from the ban the lake to the small island, her torch switched on.  38. Seeing what might be the flash of another torch in the di she stops and listens. EXT. BOAT HOUSE. NIGHT. BRIONY comes down a narrow stone alley and peers into the darkness under the boat house. Suddenly, a duck splashes from under a boat, startling her. EXT. GROTTO. NIGHT. BRIONY climbs down the steep steps into the bowl of the g Then, once again, she hesitates and slows to a standstill Suddenly, out of the darkness, there’s a painful gasp; an BRIONY whirls round, pointing her torch. For a fraction o second there’s an image of LOLA, on all fours, her dress up and a tall male figure, kneeling behind her. BRIONY dr torch in shock; it shines up in her eyes, blinding her, s the man, rising to his full height, turning and scramblin up the bank, disappears before she can pull herself toget LOLA’S voice breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Briony? BRIONY picks up the torch and shines it at LOLA, who by n in a sitting position. She hurries over to join LOLA, dro to her knees beside her.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Lola. Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I didn’t, I’m sorry... BRIONY puts her arm round LOLA’s bony shoulders; she seem strangely invigorated.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Who was it? LOLA doesn’t answer. She’s sitting up now, her arms wrapp round her knees, rocking slightly. They talk in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I saw him. I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Yes.  39.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: It was him, wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Yes. It was him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Lola... Who was it? LOLA doesn’t answer. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: It was Robbie, wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: You saw him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Like you said, he’s a sex maniac. And you don’t even know what happened before dinner. I caught him attacking my sister in the library. I don’t know what he’d have done, if I hadn’t come in...

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: You actually saw him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Of course I did. Plain as day.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: He came up behind me. He pushed me to the ground and then he put his hand over my eyes. I couldn’t actually, I never actually...

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Listen, I’ve known him all my life. And I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: LOLA
dialogues.text: Because I couldn’t say for sure.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Well, I can. And I will.  40. INT. HALL. NIGHT. LEON crosses the hall with LOLA limp in his arms, followe closely by BRIONY and CECILIA. He speaks to EMILY in an u undertone.

dialogues.speaker: LEON
dialogues.text: Call the police. And she'll be needing a doctor as well. INT. DRAWING ROOM. NIGHT. As the party surges into the room, following LEON, LOLA b into noisy tears, which continue as LEON lays her down on the sofas and EMILY tries to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: It’s all right, dear, you're all right now.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Is Robbie back?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I haven’t seen him. All this is very fast and chaotic: then BRIONY, who’s sta just inside the French windows, makes a quiet announcemen

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I know who it was. INT. LIBRARY. NIGHT. BRIONY, her face sharply lit against the dark library wal being interrogated by a stony-faced plain clothes INSPECT EMILY is scarcely visible. He rattles out the questions intimidatingly; but BRIONY’S answers are firm and unhesit

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You saw him, then?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes, I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Just as you see me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I know it was him.  41.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You know it was him, or you saw him?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes, I did. I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: With your own eyes?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes. I saw him, I saw him with my own eyes. EMILY rests a comforting hand on her daughter’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Well done, darling. EXT. TERRACE. NIGHT. CECILIA paces on the terrace, drawing hard on her cigaret she peers out into the darkness, looking for ROBBIE. INT. LANDING. NIGHT. BRIONY hesitates outside CECILIA’s room, then tries the d gingerly. It’s dark in the room. INT. CECILIA’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. BRIONY steps into the room, closes the door, turns on the crosses to CECILIA’s dressing table, opens one of the dra and begins to rummage around in it. We pass through the wall into - INT. LOLA‘S BEDROOM. NIGHT. - LOLA’s bedroom, where LOLA, is being examined by a DOCT watched by BETTY the cook. INT. CECILIA’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. BRIONY continues to rummage, opening CECILIA’s desk.  42. INT. LIBRARY. NIGHT. CECILIA is being interrogated: as with BRIONY, she’s brig lit, the INSPECTOR and EMILY are in shadow.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: My brother and I found the two of them, down by the lake.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You didn’t see anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t necessarily believe everything Briony tells you; she’s very fanciful. CECILIA'’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. BRIONY throws back the covers on CECILIA’S bed and finds, on the rumpled sheet, what she’s looking for. CECILIA’s h and in it ROBBIE’s letter. INT. LIBRARY. NIGHT. DANNY HARDMAN is being interrogated. He’s flustered, almo tearful.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: When they went looking, I went up to my Dad’s. I did, honest..

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Why was that?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: To tell him all about it. INT. LIBRARY. NIGHT. CLOSE on the letter as EMILY reads it, the INSPECTOR wait the background.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I know I shouldn’t have opened it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No. You should not. But at least you've done the right thing now.  43. INT. DRAWING ROOM. NIGHT. Tea is being served to the various POLICE OFFICERS. MARSHALL is on one of the sofas, fast asleep, his mouth o LEON, sitting isolated in an armchair, sighs and consults watch. BRIONY sits at the piano. Suppressing a yawn, she reaches forward and plonks on one of the notes two or three times the window, CECILIA has seen something. A WIDER SHOT reveals a CONSTABLE stepping into the room.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: Sir, there’s someone coming. EXT. TERRACE. NIGHT. CECILIA emerges from the house to join EMILY, BRIONY, LEO MARSHALL and the three POLICEMEN all of whom are watching motionless, the approach of a strange apparition through mist: which eventually reveals itself as ROBBIE, with PIE his shoulders and JACKSON, clinging on to his hand. EMILY sharply to BRIONY.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: It’s time you went to bed.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Now. Obediently, BRIONY turns and vanishes into the house. ROB closer now, stops in his tracks as he becomes aware of th POLICEMEN. INT. BRIONY’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. BRIONY is awake, crying into her pillow silently. She sto hearing the sound of a car starting, and jumps out of bed INT/EXT. LANDING/STAIRCASE/DRIVE. NIGHT. Briony runs across the landing and jumps up on to a windo to look out. Below is a police Humber with all four doors  44. Then ROBBIE appears, his wrists handcuffed in front of hi moving between the two CONSTABLES. One of them rounds the get into the back seat. ROBBIE stops suddenly and turns b towards the house. At the same time, EMILY’S VOICE rings

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Cecilia! BRIONY cranes forward to try to see what’s happening. CECILIA, ignoring her mother, runs to ROBBIE. ROBBIE move towards her, catching the CONSTABLE off guard for a secon catches hold of ROBBIE’s lapel and whispers into his ear. CONSTABLE arrives and disengages her hand, gently but fir then leads ROBBIE to the car and pushes him down into the seat. CECILIA bursts into tears, as the door closes. The begins to pull away from the house. Visible through the b window, as he twists round to look over his shoulder, is shocked, white face of ROBBIE. The car is only about twenty yards away from the house, w it’s obliged to slow down by the irate figure of GRACE TU clutching an umbrella, marching down the very centre of t drive. As the car passes her and before it can accelerate she brings the umbrella down with a great crash on the sh paintwork, roaring out at the top of her voice:

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Liars! Liars! Liars! BRIONY’S P.O.V.: CECILIA stands motionless, isolated belo the driveway. TRACKING SHOT: the CAMERA slowly CLOSES IN on BRIONY’s ey unblinking at the window. INT. BARN. NIGHT. ROBBIE TURNER, in a private’s uniform, is a good deal thi than when we last saw him, pale and unshaven. He’s with t corporals in the loft of a French barn: TOMMY NETTLE, a y skinny Cockney and FRANK MACE, a giant of a man, black, w once-white bandage round his large head, holding a patch one eye. He’s stuffing sacks with straw to make rough mattresses, while NETTLE tries to light a stub of candle. A CAPTION: NORTHERN FRANCE, 1940.  45.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: .«+.So I says to him: “you can sit round here twiddling your thumbs, waiting to get your head blown off if you want to, I’m off out of it”...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Ssh. He’s heard footsteps approaching the barn. NETTLE and MAC for their rifles and ROBBIE takes out a revolver. Two fig appear in the doorway, carrying something, possibly weapo it’s too dark to tell.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Bonsoir, Messieurs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Bonsoir. He whispers to the CORPORALS

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Let me do this.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Anglais? Belges?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Anglais.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: On a quelque chose pour vous. (We have something for you.)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Quoi? (What?)

dialogues.speaker: MACE
dialogues.text: What’s his game?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: He says he’s got something for us.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Fucking hell. The two FRENCHMEN take another step and ROBBIE and the CO release their safety catches.  46.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Laissez vos armes! (Put away your guns.)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Vous aussi! (Put away yours!)

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Attendez! (Wait!) One of the FRENCHMEN reaches in his pocket and brings out torch, which he uses to reveal that the two of them are c loaves and bottles. The two FRENCHMEN are obviously broth in their fifties. 1sT FRENCHMAN Ou a du manger pour vous. Du pain, du sucre... (We have some food for you. Some bread, some sugar.)

dialogues.speaker: 2ND FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Et du vin! (And some wine!) 1sT FRENCHMAN Vive 1’Angleterre.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Er, Vive la France. Later. The two FRENCHMEN sit in the loft with ROBBIE, MAC NETTLE, circulating the wine bottle.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Qu’est-ce que vous faites ici? (What are you doing here?)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Tout au commencement de la retraite, il y avait un attaque de Panzers et j'ai été séparé de ma section. (When the retreat started, Panzers attacked and I was separated from my unit.) 1sT FRENCHMAN Ah, c’est vrai, 1l’armée anglaise se retire. (So it’s true, the English are retreating.)  47.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: On va disparaitre, avant qu’il fait jour. (We'll be gone at first light.) 1sT FRENCHMAN On s’est battu toutes ces années, tant de gens sont morts. Maintenant les Allemands sont de nouveau en France. (We fought all those years, lost all those dead. Now the Germans are back in France.)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: On va revenir. On va les chasser. C’est promis. (We’ll come back. We’1ll throw them out. I promise you.) Later. Below, the FRENCHMEN smile and wave. 1sT FRENCHMAN Bonne chance! (Good luck!) They disappear into the night. NETTLE turns to ROBBIE.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Come on, then. How come a toff like you, talks French and everything, ends up a private? ROBBIE hesitates, then decides to be forthcoming.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Not eligible for officer training if you join direct from prison.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: You’re pulling my tit.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m not: they gave me a choice, stay in prison or join the army. They’re looking at him with increased respect, as he adds quietly:

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: And, for the record, the last thing I am is a toff. He leans back against the wall, lost in thought.  48. INT. JOE LYONS CORNER HOUSE IN THE STRAND. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK IN TIME.
dialogues.text: ROBBIE, in uniform, looks through the glass separating th from the café and sees CECILIA, in her nurse’s uniform, s at a table near the back. Suddenly overcome with nerves, turns away, facing the cloak-room, where he tries to get better of his fears. When he turns back, CECILIA, lit by of sunlight, is standing by her table, looking at him. RO pushes into the cafe and moves over to her. For a moment, stand in awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’m late, I got lost.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hello. A short silence.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Shall we sit down?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. She’s already ordered tea and now she pours him a cup. He hesitates over the sugar bowl.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I’m afraid I can’t remember...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Two, thank you. He begins stirring his tea; CECILIA puts a hand over his. moment passes, then he gently takes his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Where are you living?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Tiny flat in Balham. It’s ghastly. The landlady’s rude and horribly nosey.  49.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You look the same, apart from the uniform of course.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I have to be back at the hospital in half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, God, that’s... He breaks off, mastering his dismay. Two OLD LADIES are gossiping at a nearby table.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No...Have you been in touch with your family?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I’ve told you, I’m not going to. Leon came and waited outside the hospital last week. But I just pushed past him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Cee, you don’t...owe me anything.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Didn’t you read my letters? Had they let me visit you, had I been allowed...every day...I’d have been there every day.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yes. But if all we have rests on a few moments in the library three and a half years ago, then I’m not sure...I don’t know if... CECILIA puts her hand on his.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Look at me. He does so. He’s close to tears.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Come back. Come back to me. She reaches out and puts a hand on his cheek; he inclines head, holding her hand between his cheek and his shoulder  50. INT. BARN. NIGHT. ROBBIE lies awake, hearing the snoring of the CORPORALS. barn owl sits on an adjacent beam staring at ROBBIE, who’ composing a letter in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dearest Cecilia... Dearest Cecilia... Cecilia... EXT. WHITEHALL. DAY. CUT BACK IN TIME. ROBBIE is walking CECILIA to the bus stop, through millin crowds, many in uniform, past sandbags piled high in shop entrances.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: A friend of mine has a cottage by the coast; she says we can use it when you’re next on leave. White clapboard with blue painted window frames. They look at each other; then he kisses her, a long, deep CECILIA starts to cry. A bus pulls up beside them. CECILI hurriedly produces a photograph of the cottage and hands ROBBIE.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Something to think about while you’re away. She tears herself away and scrambles aboard the bus. She on the platform, looking back at ROBBIE and the bus start and moves away.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I love you. ROBBIE starts to run after the bus, but soon it accelerat away, leaving him marooned in the middle of the road, the traffic passing either side of him.  51. EXT. BARN. DAWN. ROBBIE sits outside the barn in the pearly dawn light. He looking at the now somewhat battered photograph of the co which is attached to a bundle of letters, which he now pu in an inside pocket. Then, checking to make sure he’s not watched, he opens his shirt to reveal, at his solar plexu wound about the size of an old penny. It doesn’t look too just red and sore. But when he presses on it, he gasps in and the wound releases a flow of colourless liquid. EXT. FIELDS. DAWN. The three soldiers move across a field, silhouetted again rising sun. They move along the bank of a narrow canal, in which are reflected the shapes of three German bombers, passing ove

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Some poor sod’s going to catch a packet. EXT. STREET IN BALHAM. DAY. CUT BACK IN TIME. CECILIA moves briskly down the street with a letter in he

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My darling, Briony found my address somehow and sent a letter. The first surprise was she didn’t go up to Cambridge. She’s doing nurse’s training at my old hospital. I think she may be doing this as some kind of penance. She says she’s beginning to get the full grasp of what she did and what it meant. She wants to come and talk to me. She kisses the letter and posts it.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I love you. I’1l wait for you.  52. INT. POSTBOX. DAY. The letter falls on to the pile of other letters.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come back. Come back to me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come back. EXT. APPLE ORCHARD. DAY. ROBBIE, MACE and NETTLE move cautiously through a mist-sh orchard.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come back. Come back. NETTLE, who's limping a little, comes to a ragged halt.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Where are we going, guv? He suddenly sits down on the ground and, with a cry of ra pulls off his boots and hurls them into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: I fucking hate those boots. I hate them worse than all the fucking Germans put together!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You'll have a job getting back to England in your socks. ROBBIE trudges off through the trees to retrieve NETTLE’s He approaches the area where he thinks NETTLE’s boots mig fallen, a little out of sight of the CORPORALS, finds the picks them up, wearily removes his tin hat, mops his brow closes his red-rimmed eyes. When he opens his eyes again, notices something, frowns and advances a few paces. In a clearing in the orchard, lying in neatly organised r are the corpses of thirty GIRLS, all around 13, dressed i neat black and white uniform of a convent school. ROBBIE looks down at them, appalled and moved.  53. EXT. RIVER-BANK NEAR THE TALLIS HOUSE. DAY. CUT BACK IN TIME. There’s a natural pool not far from the weir in the river flows through the woods at the far end of the Tallis Hous grounds. ROBBIE finishes dressing, picks up a damp towel and emerg the trees to find BRIONY, still in her swimsuit, standing jump-off point, wrapped in a towel.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Come on, pal. You should be getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: If I fell in the river, would you save me?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Of course. As ROBBIE bends down to do up his shoelace, there’s a lou splash. He looks up. BRIONY has disappeared, her towel li where she stood. Horrified, ROBBIE moves forward to look the river. BRIONY surfaces for a second, then goes under again. She’ drifting towards the weir. ROBBIE doesn’t hesitate. He di into the river. EXT. UNDERWATER. ROBBIE flounders around in the greenish murk. Then he see flash of white and the bubbles rising round BRIONY’s flai limbs. He swims powerfully towards her. EXT. RIVER-BANK. DAY. ROBBIE drops BRIONY in the shallow water near the bank an strides ashore, furious. BRIONY, on the other hand, seems delighted.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you, thank you...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: That was an incredibly bloody stupid thing to do.  54.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I wanted you to save me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Don’t you know how easily you could have drowned?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: You saved me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You stupid child! You could have killed us both! Is that your idea of a joke? She looks at him for a moment, shocked by his tone, but d nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I want to thank you for saving my life. I’ll be eternally grateful to you. He strides away angrily, into the woods, leaving BRIONY disconsolate amidst the cow parsley. EXT. RIVER-BANK IN FRANCE. DAY. ROBBIE leads MACE and NETTLE northwards beside a broad ri

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The story can resume. Our story can resume. I will simply resume. NETTLE’s insistent voice breaks into his reverie.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Let’s see Jerry come and have a go at us in fucking Southend. Or, better still, Trafalgar Square. No one speaks the fucking lingo out here. You can’t say “Pass the biscuit” or “Where’s me hand grenade?” They just shrug. Because they hate us too. I mean, that’s the point. We fight in France and the French fucking hate us. Make me Home Secretary, I’1ll sort this out in a fucking minute. We got India and Africa, right? Jerry can have France and Belgium and whatever else they want. Who’s fucking ever been to Poland? It’s all about room, empire. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NETTLE (cont'd) They want more empire. Give’em this shithole, we keep ours, and it’s Bob’s your uncle and Fanny’s your fucking aunt. Think about it. EXT. SLUICE. DUSK. It’s late afternoon and the sun is low in the sky as ROBB the CORPORALS trudge past some kind of sluice which squat across a broad canal. They’re approaching the outskirts o industrial quarter of Dunkirk, close enough now to see th pall of black smoke rising above the town. EXT. RAILWAY BRIDGE. NIGHT. ROBBIE is trying to get some sleep under a stone railway watched by an impassive bullfrog.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dearest Cecilia, the story can resume. EXT. BEACH BELOW WHITE CLIFFS. DAY. On a deserted shingle beach, beneath towering chalk cliff CECILIA sits, looking out to sea towards France.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The one I had been planning on that evening walk. I can become again the man who once walked across a Surrey park at dusk in my best suit, swaggering on the promise of life; the man who, with the clarity of passion, made love to you in the library. The story can resume. EXT. INDUSTRIAL QUARTER. DAY. The three soldiers tramp along between narrow-gauge railw lines.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I will return. Find you, love you, marry you, and live without shame.  56. A WIDE ANGLE reveals that ROBBIE, MACE and NETTLE are mov past an enormous burning steelworks ringed with deep bomb craters, with destroyed vehicles at precarious angles. EXT. APPROACH TO BRAY DUNES. DAY. ROBBIE and his companions move along a straight road betw patches of scrub grass, the industrial quarter now behind Suddenly, ROBBIE raises his head.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I can smell the sea. He sets off at a run, along a path cut through long grass and NETTLE labouring behind. EXT. BRAY DUNES. DAY. ROBBIE scrambles up the final steep dune and stops. NETTL MACE join him, their jaws dropping in amazement. They are looking down at an astonishing scene. Beyond the beach at Bray is teeming with SOLDIERS, hundreds of thous men as far as the eye can see. The few ships there are, o the iron-grey Channel, are almost all capsized or ablaze; most striking of all, what looks at first sight like a se jetties turns out to be columns of SOLDIERS, six or eight standing out to sea for almost five hundred yards in the waters, the closest submerged up to their knees, the furt obliged to hold their rifles up above their tin helmets t them dry. The three MEN watch for a moment in silence, be MACE gives out a heavy sigh.

dialogues.speaker: MACE
dialogues.text: Fuck me, it’s like something out the Bible. For once, NETTLE is at a loss for words.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. ROBBIE shakes his head as if to clear it. EXT. BEACH AT BRAY DUNES. DAY. ROBBIE wanders with the others through what seems like a hallucination.  57. Harnessed but riderless horses gallop across the sand. A with ragged black sails lies fifty yards from the sea. A football game is in progress. A small group of men throw their clothes and splash into the sea for a swim. Another group huddles in a bandstand, singing a hymn. A chaplain and his clerk are throwing prayer books and bi into a bonfire; the thin pages catch and float into the a black snowflakes. A YOUNG SOLDIER of no more than 17 sits quietly looking out to sea with tears streaming down his ROBBIE approaches a group of NAVAL OFFICERS, as they stri the beach with a clipboard, trying to do a head-count. Th moving briskly throughout the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: We've just arrived, Sir. Can you tell us what we’re supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: NAVAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just wait.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Where are the ships?

dialogues.speaker: NAVAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: A few made it in yesterday but the Luftwaffe blew them to buggery. We lost five hundred men when they sank the Endurance. And high command in its infinite wisdom is denying us air cover. It’s a disgrace, it’s a fucking disaster.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: The thing is, I’m expected back, you see.

dialogues.speaker: NAVAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: There’s over three hundred thousand men on this beach, private. So you’1l have to wait your turn. Just be grateful that you’re not wounded, we've had orders to leave the wounded behind. NETTLE pulls ROBBIE away, as the NAVAL OFFICER continues beach.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Come on, guv, never trust a sailor on dry land. Best off out of it.  58. ROBBIE moves on, dazed, through crowds streaming across t beach in opposite directions, past gutted and blazing veh From up ahead, the SOUND of a gunshot.

dialogues.speaker: MACE
dialogues.text: That’s not right. To one side is a detachment of French cavalry, each man dismounted and standing to attention beside his horse. A OFFICER with a pistol moves slowly, almost ceremoniously, the line, shooting each horse in the head. ROBBIE moves on, as another horse goes down in the backgr He rounds the back of the beached whaler where a deranged SOLDIER is perched up on the mast, furiously waving and s at the top of his voice.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Can you hear me, laddies? I’m coming home. The seafront, or what’s left of it was once a cheerful re with cafes and little shops. ROBBIE, MACE and NETTLE pass bandstand and merry-go-round decorated in red, white and Soldiers have opened up the cafes and a good portion of t raucously drunk. Some lark about on bikes. A solitary sun in his underpants lies on a towel. A brawling couple roll the bank on to the beach. MACE climbs up on to the gazebo-shaped bandstand where a knot of SOLDIERS is singing “Dear Lord and Father of Mank Then he catches up with ROBBIE and NETTLE as they plunge ahead.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Come on. I have to get something to drink.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: You need one. You’re grey. He turns to MACE.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
