dialogues.text: He’s gone all grey, look. They move on past another group of SOLDIERS, disabling ve with their rifle-butts. Then ROBBIE points ahead to where cinema sits, perched unexpectedly at the top of the beach  59.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: There. Come on. He scrambles up a wooden stairway and disappears into the cinema, having taken one last appraising look out across raucous inferno of the beach. INT. CINEMA BAR. DAY. ROBBIE pushes his way through a tight crowd of SOLDIERS, singing “The Long and the Short and the Tall” with the wo changed from “Bless’em all” to “Fuck’em all”. He can’t fi anything to drink, and, as a brawl starts up and bottles to fly, he ducks through a door at the back. INT. BACKSTAGE AREA. DAY. ROBBIE finds a tap on the wall in a kind of box-room, clu with film cannisters; he tries it, but nothing comes out. background, the SONG has changed to “The White Cliffs of but ROBBIE has heard, under this, the murmur of French di and he moves forward to investigate. INT. CINEMA. DAY. ROBBIE scrambles down a ladder and finds himself at the f a giant screen where the huge face, full of doomed melanc of Jean Gabin leans forward to kiss the shining lips of M Morgan in Quai des Brumes. As Gabin kisses her a second t ROBBIE, dwarfed by the enormous black-and-white image, bu his face in his hands. EXT. STREET IN BRAY. NIGHT. ROBBIE wanders down a rubble-strewn street, between blazi buildings and vehicles; NETTLE, accompanying him, cups hi around his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Mace! Mace! They turn a corner and NETTLE, demoralised, stops to ligh cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Hold up, guv.  60. ROBBIE , looking listlessly around, sees an elderly FRENC step into a shop with shattered windows. His interest abr aroused, he speaks crisply to NETTLE.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Wait here. He sets off into the shop, leaving a bemused NETTLE. INT. SHOP. NIGHT. ROBBIE moves into a kind of parlour off the main shop. He around; he’s sweating now and very pale. Suddenly, a fami VOICE breaks into his reverie.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why don’t you sit down? ROBBIE turns to find the reassuring figure of GRACE, his standing in a doorway. Gratefully, he sinks into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It’s so hot in here.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Take your boots off. Later. GRACE is washing ROBBIE’s feet. They exchange a te smile.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I have to get back. I promised her. To put things right. And she loves me. She's waiting for me. GRACE looks up at him, infinitely understanding. There’s explosion outside. EXT. STREET. NIGHT. ROBBIE strides out of the shop, carrying bread and wine, longer wearing his boots. NETTLE, who’s sitting waiting, obliged to jump to his feet and hurry after him.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Oi! Wait! NETTLE catches up with ROBBIE.  él.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: What you done with your boots? No answer. NETTLE circles ROBBIE, trying to get his atten

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: You sure you're feeling all right?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Never better. He moves on, frowning in concentration.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Now, I’m wondering if the beach really is the best place for dinner. EXT. SIDE STREET. NIGHT. ROBBIE and NETTLE turn into a side street, as bombs explo not far away, and the night is lit up by flashes of artil

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, I don’t recognise it... NETTLE follows, scrambling over rubble and bomb debris. H indicates a dark opening.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: This’1l do. Down here.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, no, it’s a little further on.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: This place I know, an old cottage, white clapboard with blue painted window frames. NETTLE finally understands he’s delirious and decides to along with him, whilst manoeuvering him towards the entra an abandoned ice factory.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, that’s right, that’s where we're going.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It’s close to here.  62.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: We’re there. This is it. He succeeds in leading ROBBIE into the side entrance of t factory. INT. ICE FACTORY. NIGHT. NETTLE guides ROBBIE between ranks of sleeping SOLDIERS, arriving at a steel staircase leading down to a cellar.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Here we are. Down here. INT. STAIRCASE AND CELLAR. NIGHT. ROBBIE descends the narrow staircase, NETTLE following. T cellar is also crowded, but they reach an empty stretch o and NETTLE starts to help ROBBIE off with his pack. As he so, ROBBIE more or less collapses.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: It’s all right, guv’nor. He straightens ROBBIE out and drapes a thin blanket over

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: That’s right. Get your head down. There you go. Tuck yourself in. Keep yourself warm. NETTLE hands ROBBIE a chunk of bread.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Chew on a bit of this but quiet like or they’1l1 all be wanting some. And try and get some sleep. Ssh. Having calmed ROBBIE, NETTLE settles himself down facing Darkness. Then a match flares. It’s ROBBIE: he has the bu letters in his hand, and the photograph of the cottage on coast. SOUND of the sea. Slowly the match burns out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Key moments from ROBBIE’s past, some familiar, some not, some running backwards. The fragment of Meissen flies back up out of the fountain attaches itself to the lip of the vase.  63. ROBBIE takes back the letter he’s handed to BRIONY. The hammers of ROBBIE’s typewriter lift the ink from the N-U-C, leaving clean white paper. ROBBIE, alone, advances through a poppy-field in France, blazing sun.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Find you, love you, marry you, and live without shame. The Dunkirk cinema is filled with SOLDIERS singing “The W Cliffs of Dover.” As Jean Gabin kisses Michéle Morgan, ROBBIE raises his fa from his hands. A SLOW TRACKING SHOT finds CECILIA, in her green evening standing outside the Tallis House. ROBBIE’s arrest, played backwards: he backs away from the breaks away momentarily from the CONSTABLE escorting him. CLOSE on CECILIA: She leans forward and whispers into ROB ear.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I love you. Come back. Come back to me. INT. CELLAR. NIGHT. ROBBIE comes awake with a start; NETTLE is gently shaking

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Bit too much noise, guv’nor.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Noise? What noise?

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: You keep shouting. Some of the lads are getting a bit peeved. ROBBIE tries to lift his head but can’t. NETTLE strikes a

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Christ. You look a bit rough.  64.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Thing is, I've decided to stay ona bit. I’m meeting someone. I’m always keeping her waiting. NETTLE wipes the sweat off ROBBIE’S forehead; he begins t speak, his voice soothing.

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Now listen, listen to me, guv’nor. I went out for a Jimmy Riddle just now. Guess what I saw? They’re getting themselves sorted out down on the beach. The boats are back and a geezer from the Buffs is marching us down at seven. We're away, we're off home, mate! So get some more sleep and no more of your bleeding shouting, all right? ROBBIE looks peaceful. He speaks in a cracked whisper:

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I won't say a word. Wake me before seven, would you? Thanks so much. You won't hear another word out of me. I promise. FADE TO BLACK. INT. CORRIDOR AND WARD IN ST.THOMAS'S HOSPITAL. DAY. A broad, empty hospital corridor, simonized to an improba gloss. A CAPTION: LONDON, THREE WEEKS EARLIER. The SOUND of rapid, regular steps at the far end of the corridor. Then they appear, a group of PROBATIONARY NURSE following a WARD SISTER, like ducklings after their mothe At the back of the group is BRIONY TALLIS, now eighteen, dressed, like the others, in the constricting purple and tunic of a probationer. SISTER DRUMMOND, a woman in her thirties with a narrow mo a quiet but lethal delivery, and her NURSES sweep into a ward with high ceilings and windows.  65.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: Bed castors should be lined up and pointing inwards. I found three yesterday that weren’t. You know who you are. They keep walking, moving fast.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: Which of you was responsible for putting away the blankets today? An amiable-looking nurse, FIONA AVERY, pipes up apprehens

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I was, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: I don’t suppose you can tell us what you did wrong.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: No, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: Labels are folded to the inside, are they not?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, Sister, sorry, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: Do them again. Nurse Tallis, I'll see you in my office. The rest of you are excused. BRIONY follows SISTER DRUMMOND towards her office. INT. SISTER'S OFFICE. DAY. BRIONY stands across from SISTER DRUMMOND, who sits at he

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: Is this job at all important to you, Tallis?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Very important, Sister.  66.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: Yesterday you were seconded to men’s surgical. When your patient came round from his anaesthetic, it seems the first thing he did was to ask for Briony. Who might Briony be?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Well, me, Sister. SISTER DRUMMOND suddenly draws herself up and shouts at B

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: There is no Briony! You are Tallis. Nurse Tallis. Is that understood?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: BRIONY stands at a window at the end of a long corridor l out at a view of the Thames and Parliament beyond. The su setting. Her focus shifts to her own reflection which she studies impassively for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: There is no Briony. She turns from the window and walks away down the corrido past people putting up the blackout shutters. Over this, VOICE of a RADIO NEWSREADER.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the B.B.C Home Service. Here is the news. The B.E.F., with their French allies, are fighting a desperate battle in the Northern Zone of the Western Front. The Allied Forces have not lost cohesion and their morale is high. The R.A.F. continues to give all the support in its power to the Allied armies in Northern France... INT. NURSES’ DORMITORY. NIGHT. The CAMERA moves slowly through the 20-bed dormitory, tak jars of cosmetics, overflowing ashtrays and tennis racque the corridor a NURSE stands at the wall-mounted telephone talking to each one of her family in turn.  67. Back in the dormitory, NURSES are putting in curlers, wri letters, crying gently on one another’s shoulder, dancing Flanagan and Allen record. Finally, we arrive at BRIONY, trimming the nails on FIONA’S right hand.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Thanks, I never could make the scissors work with my left hand. Mummy always did it for me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: There. You’re done. She turns to her bedside locker, in which is the small po typewriter she used as a child. Somebody shouts “Lights out!” And the lights go out.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Oh, bother. BRIONY lies back on her bed.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Good night, Tallis. INT. WATER TANK ROOM. ST. THOMAS’ HOSPITAL. NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The water tank room is high in a tower above the hospital SOUND of someone typing. BRIONY is perched on a step, amo pipes and tanks, typing furiously. Beside her, a small pi paper. A noise at the bottom of the stairs. BRIONY is startled.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Don’t panic. It’s only me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Fiona! I almost jumped out of my skin! FIONA climbs up. She’s wearing her dressing gown. She sit fishes for a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: So this is what you get up to after lights out. I thought you might be in the middle of some tempestuous romance. She shivers.  68.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Don’t you freeze to death up here? She moves to look out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I love London. Do you think all of this will be bombed and just disappear?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: No. I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Do you write about Sister Drummond? Do you write about me?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Can I look?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I'd rather you didn’t. It’s private. She puts out a hand to cover the title page, which reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figures By a Fountain by Briony Tallis.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I don’t see any point in writing a story if you're not going to let anyone read it.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: It’s not ready yet.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: What’s it about ?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: It’s just...it’s about a young girl, a young and foolish girl, who sees something from her nursery window which she doesn’t understand, but she thinks she does...I probably won't ever finish it. FIONA considers BRIONY for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I look at you, Tallis, and you’re so mysterious. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIONA (cont'd) I’ve never been mysterious. Do you know what I decided tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I could never marry a man who wasn’t in the Royal Navy. BRIONY thinks about this, then bursts out laughing. FIONA shushes her, giggling helplessly herself.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATION OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: A sympathetic-looking ASSISTANT with an index-card in her turns to speak to BRIONY, who’s in uniform, waiting on th side of the counter.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Here we are, Cecilia Tallis, I think this is her address.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Thank you. INT. WARD. NIGHT. BRIONY, on night duty, sits at her table studying textboo

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Cecilia, Please don’t throw this away without reading it. As you’1ll have seen from the notepaper, I’m here at St. Thomas's, doing my nurses’ training. INT. SLUICE ROOM. DAY. BRIONY, in a heavy rubber apron, sluices a bedpan, lookin holding her breath.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I decided not to take up my place at Cambridge. I decided I wanted to make myself useful, do something practical.  70. INT. HOSPITAL CORRIDOR. DAY. BRIONY and FIONA are polishing the floors using a heavy b that they can hardly move from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: It says in the paper the army are making strategic withdrawals.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I saw that. It’s a euphemism for retreat. EXT. HOSPITAL YARD. DAY. BRIONY works alongside a number of other PROBATIONERS, on knees in the centre of the yard, scrubbing the frame of o number of filthy old beds.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But no matter how hard I work, no matter how long the hours, I can’t escape from what I did... INT. WASH ROOM. NIGHT. BRIONY stands at the only (cold) tap, fiercely scrubbing hands with a scrubbing-brush and baking soda. Her hands a raw, cracked and marked with chilblains.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...and what it meant, the full extent of which I’m only now beginning to grasp. Cee, please write and tell me we can meet. Your sister, Briony. INT. STORE ROOM. DAY. BRIONY works in a corner near the doorway, with FIONA. Fr time to time PORTERS arrive with trolleys and leave piles boxes outside in the corridor. Other NURSES unpack and st kidney bowls and packs of hypodermics.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: So do you?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Do I what?  71.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Have a secret fiance in France? That’s what everybody thinks.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: No. Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Imagine not knowing if he’d ever come back.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I’ve never been in love.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: What never? Not even a crush?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I had a crush once, when I was ten or eleven. I jumped in the river to see if he’d save me from drowning.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Now you’re teasing me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: No. And he did save me. But as soon as I told him I loved him the feeling sort of disappeared. Outside in the corridor, there’s a commotion. People are past. Another PROBATIONARY NURSE sticks her head through doorway.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Something's happened. BRIONY and FIONA put down the boxes they’re stacking and into the corridor, where everyone is running towards the EXT. ENTRANCE TO ST. THOMAS’S HOSPITAL. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As BRIONY and FIONA arrive, out of breath, bloody and wou SOLDIERS are being unloaded from the lorries and ambulanc Many of them are black with oil, coated in grime and daze exhaustion. BRIONY has scarcely arrived, when a young REG barks at her.

dialogues.speaker: REGISTRAR
dialogues.text: You! Get on the end of this stretcher!  72. He turns away from her and picks up the stretcher, handle behind him, so that he doesn’t see the vast effort it cos BRIONY to lift her end. The PATIENT is a large SERGEANT, bare feet and filthy bluish toes directly below BRIONY’s his thigh disfigured by an ugly wound. BRIONY struggles f each step plainly an agony for her and, even more distres for the SERGEANT. INT. SECOND FLOOR. CORRIDOR. DAY. The lift doors slam open and the REGISTRAR emerges carryi stretcher. BRIONY is struggling desperately along behind REGISTRAR, her teeth gritted, her face puce with effort. PATIENT utters a fearsome groan. Tears begin to roll down BRIONY’s cheeks as she gasps with effort, the fingers of left hand begin inexorably to unravel. She hangs on griml they turn into the ward. INT. WARD. DAY. A NURSE and a SISTER wait by an emergency bed in a ward n crammed with extra beds. The REGISTRAR and BRIONY arrive alongside and stop. BRIONY’s left hand gives way and she’ obliged to catch the stretcher on her knee. This causes a anguished gasp from the PATIENT. The REGISTRAR glares at BRIONY turns and hurries away, glancing surreptitiously a red and dented left hand. EXT. HOSPITAL ENTRANCE. DAY. BRIONY emerges into a scene of escalating chaos as more a field ambulances arrive and dozens of wounded soldiers mi about hopelessly or sit waiting on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Fucking shambles.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Turner! Private Turner? BRIONY spins on her heels. There is a slight man, his fac filthy and black with oil. It is ROBBIE.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Robbie? Robbie! ROBBIE turns away. BRIONY rushes to him, puts a hand on h and turns him forcibly. The man is not ROBBIE.  73.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. INT. BRIONY’S WARD. DAY INTO NIGHT A MONTAGE of BRIONY’s work against a background of ceasel activity in the rest of the ward. BRIONY helps lift a man leg has been amputated back on to his bed. BRIONY swabs the oil from a long, stitched wound down a m back. BRIONY leans forward, puts one hand on an AIRMAN’s leg, g the end of a protruding piece of shrapnel with the forcep pulls it out, firmly and smoothly. BRIONY rips a dressing off a man’s chest, causing him to and vomit. BRIONY joins a group of NURSES around the bed of a young whose body is entirely covered in savage oil burns. Outside in the hallway, FIONA, overcome, turns towards th and weeps. INT. WARD. NIGHT. BRIONY moves between rows of sleeping patients, checking She’s intercepted by SISTER DRUMMOND.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: You speak a little French, if I remember rightly.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Only school French, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: The soldier over there in bed 13. Go and sit with him for a minute. Hold his hand. BRIONY hesitates, looking over towards the soldier.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: Off you go. BRIONY slowly moves down the length of the ward, full of apprehension. Bed 13 is surrounded by screens. Inside the screens is the patient, LUC CORNET, his head heavily band  74. He’s asleep. BRIONY sits by the bed and hesitantly takes hand. He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Te voila, enfin. (Here you are, at last.)

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: La soeur m’a envoyée. Pour bavarder un peu. (The Sister sent me. For a little chat.)

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Ah, oui, je me souviens de ta soeur. Elle était toujours trés gentille. Qu’est-ce qu’elle fait maintenant? (Oh, yes, I remember your sister. She was always so nice. What’s she doing now?)

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Erm, elle est aussi infirmiére. (She’s a nurse as well.)

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Est-ce qu’elle s’est mariée enfin avec cet homme qu’elle aimait tant? J’ai oublié son nom. (Did she finally marry that man she was so in love with? I’ve forgotten his name.)

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Er, Robbie. Bientét, j’espére. (She will soon, I hope.)

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Robbie, oui, c’est ga. (Robbie, yes, that’s right.)

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Et vous, comment vous appellez-vous? (And what’‘s your name?)

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Luc. Luc Cornet. Et toi? BRIONY hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Tallis.  75.

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Tallis. C’est joli. (That’‘s pretty.) A spasm of pain or bewilderment crosses his face. He grip hand tightly and looks at her, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Je me rappelle de toi maintenant. C’est 1’Anglaise. Tu te souviens, ta premiére visite a Millau? Je travaillais avec mon pére prés des fours. J'ai entendu ton accent. (I remember you now. You’re the English girl. You remember your first visit to Millau? I was working by the ovens with my father. I heard your accent.) BRIONY looks at him, moved by his confusion.

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Tu peux me rendre un tout petit service, Tallis? (Can you do me a little favour?)

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Bien sfr. (Of course.)

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Ce bandage me serre terriblement. Tu peux le desserrer un peu? S‘il te plait. (These bandages are so tight. Can you loosen them a bit? Please.) BRIONY stands to look down at the bandage. It’s secured b pair of simple gauze bows. She begins to undo them.

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Tu te souviens de ma soeur cadette, Anne? Elle joue toujours ce petit morceau de Debussy. Tu te souviens? (You remember my younger sister, Anne? She still plays that little Debussy piece. Do you remember?) He starts to hum the tune. BRIONY continues to unwind the bandages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle prend toujours une mine si grave quand elle joue, tu ne trouves pas? (She always looks so serious when she plays, you know?) All of a sudden, the sterile towel underneath the bandage away, taking most of the bloodstained dressing with it. A section of CORNET’s skull is missing and BRIONY finds her looking directly down at his brain.

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Et nos croissants? Qu’est-ce que tu en pensais? (What about our croissants? What did you think of them?) Methodically, not panicking, BRIONY starts to replace the dressing.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Délicieux. Les plus délicieux a Millau. (Delicious. The most delicious in Millau.)

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Oui, c’est la qualité du beurre. (Yes, it’s the quality of the butter.)

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Oui. (Yes.)

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: C’est pour ga que tu venais tous les jours? (Is that why you came every day?)

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Oui, bien sar. (Yes, of course.) CORNET thinks for a moment. Meanwhile, with infinite care BRIONY is replacing the sterile towel.

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Parce que, tu sais... Ma mére t’aime beaucoup. (Because, you know...my mother is very fond of you.)  77.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Ah, bon? (Oh, yes?)

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Oui. A son avis, on devrait se marier pendant 1’été. (Yes. In her opinion we should get married in the summer.) BRIONY falters in her work, but recovers. She’s tying the of the bandage.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: C’est plus confortable comme ga, j’éspére. (I hope that’s more comfortable. )

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Tu m’aimes? (Do you love me?)

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Oui. (Yes.) She’s spoken without hesitation. He’s broken into a light and she leans forward to wipe his face tenderly. He looks her.

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: Tu peux rester un peu? (Can you stay a while?) BRIONY nods reassuringly. All of a sudden, it’s as if an electric current has passed through him. He jerks upright begins to topple forward. BRIONY catches him and his head forward, banging against her cheek. It’s all she can do t him back to his previous position in the bed. She’s settl him, her face close to his, when his eyes flutter open. A rolls down his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CORNET
dialogues.text: J'ai peur. J'ai peur. Tallis. (I'm frightened. I’m frightened, Tallis.)

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Briony. Je m‘appelle Briony. (My name is Briony.) She’s suddenly aware of SISTER DRUMMOND standing above he speaks with her habitual sinister softness.  78.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: Stand up, Nurse Tallis. BRIONY does, bracing herself for an onslaught which doesn come. Instead, DRUMMOND reaches out to straighten BRIONY’ collar. Behind her, a NURSE covers LUC CORNET’S face with sheet. Finally, DRUMMOND speaks, an unprecedented note of tenderness in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMOND
dialogues.text: Now go and wash the blood off your face. Numbly, BRIONY turns away and sets off down the centre of silent, darkened ward. INT. HOSPITAL DAY ROOM. DAY. Open on full-screen newsreel footage: the return of the B France. The newsreel is being shown on a makeshift screen day room, where it is being watched with various degrees disbelief and disgust by those of the patients well enoug up and about. In total contrast to everything we've seen hospital and at Dunkirk, what’s shown tells of a heroic r and a triumphant return. We see the troops offering smili faces and giving the thumbs-up as train carriages roll in London. We see Union Jacks waving, and happy wives and ch

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The navy has earned our undying gratitude. The army is undefeated. Courage has brought them through unconquered, their spirit unbowed. This is the epic of Dunkirk, a name that will live forever in the annals of warfare. BRIONY stands at the back, watching this propaganda. The item in the newsreel is introduced by a title: ON THE HOM FRONT.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the course of a comprehensive tour, Queen Elizabeth is seen here visiting a chocolate factory in the North of England... On the screen the Queen is being given a tour of the ARMY factory. BRIONY begins to collect her things to leave. Su her attention is caught, as there, on the screen, she see QUINCEY and PAUL MARSHALL shaking hands with the Queen.  79.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: The confectionery magnate, and friend of the British Army, Mr. Paul Marshall, gave the Queen a tour of the Army Amo factory with his lovely soon- to-be-wed fiancee Miss Lola Quincey. And what a mouthwatering couple they are. Keep the Amo coming, our boys have a sweet tooth! LOLA looks at the camera and smiles, as if straight at BR EXT. CHURCH OF THE HOLY TRINITY, CLAPHAM. DAY. The church stands at the end of a street of terraced hous imposing facade behind pillars and a flight of steps. BRI approaches, moving up the street, taking note of an empty Rolls Royce parked outside the church. She hesitantly cli steps towards the church door. INT. CHURCH OF THE HOLY TRINITY. DAY. The wedding is already in progress, as BRIONY quietly let herself into the church. There are a large number of GUESTS. PIERROT and JACKSON, fourteen, stand between their estranged parents, HERMIONE CECIL. On the other side are the many GUESTS of MARSHALL. in full bridal white and heavily veiled, and MARSHALL in morning suit, face the VICAR, who is in full flow. BRIONY slips into a pew at the back and watches.

dialogues.speaker: VICAR
dialogues.text: Secondly for a remedy against sin, and to avoid fornication, that such persons as have not the gift of continence might marry and keep themselves undefiled members of Christ's body. Thirdly, it was ordained for the mutual society, help and comfort, that the one ought to have for the other... The VOICE of YOUNG BRIONY breaks in, talking to the POLIC INSPECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I saw him. BRIONY sits in her seat, an appalling knowledge dawning.  80.

dialogues.speaker: VICAR
dialogues.text: Therefore if any man can show any just cause, why they may not be lawfully joined together, let him now speak, or for ever hold his peace. BRIONY’s fingers grip her seat.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know it was him. EXT. GRASSY BANK NEAR THE TALLIS HOUSE. NIGHT. 1935.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIONY stands still, blinded by the torch. INT. CHURCH OF THE HOLY TRINITY. DAY. 1940.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIONY’s eyes widen. EXT. GRASSY BANK NEAR THE TALLIS HOUSE. NIGHT. 1935.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time it’s clear that the figure scrambling away up t is PAUL MARSHALL. A CRASH of organ music. INT. LIBRARY. NIGHT. YOUNG BRIONY faces the INSPECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I saw him, I saw him with my own eyes. The church organ thunders on. INT. CHURCH OF THE HOLY TRINITY. DAY. 1940.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIONY stands in her pew as LOLA and MARSHALL walk toward They don’t notice her until the VICAR swings open one of great doors of the church. A shaft of sunlight sweeps acr shining straight on BRIONY. She stares at LOLA and MARSHA they draw level with her. LOLA’S eyes meet with BRIONY’S, forehead crinkles with displeasure, her lips purse. MARSH face reddens and then they are gone. BRIONY is left alone in the church.  81. EXT. STREET NEAR BALHAM. DAY. BRIONY passes down a narrow terrace of red-brick houses. towards her is a MOTHER with four unruly BOYS, all carryi cardboard suitcases and knapsacks.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Leave off, let the nursey through! The BOYS take no notice of her whatsoever, and BRIONY is to stand aside to let them pass. The MOTHER smiles at her apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: They’re going down to the country today. Never been out of London before.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I hope they get a nice family.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: They dunno what they’re in for with this lot! EXT. DUDLEY VILLAS IN BALHAM. DAY. BRIONY walks down the long, drab street and stops at no.4 outside which is an old Ford 8 without wheels, supported piles of brick. She walks down the front path, rings the doorbell and then, realizing it doesn’t work, uses the he knocker to knock twice. The door is opened by a sour-face woman in her thirties, MRS. JARVIS.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I’m looking for Miss Tallis. Cecilia Tallis. Is she in? MRS.JARVIS turns and yells up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JARVIS
dialogues.text: Tallis! Door! Eventually, CECILIA appears in the doorway. She’s wearing striped dressing-gown and men’s socks.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: My God.  82.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I tried writing, but you wouldn’t answer. I have to talk to you. INT. CECILIA'S FLAT. DAY. CECILIA leads BRIONY to her tiny kitchen/living room. Eve - furniture, lino, wallpaper - is cheap and shabby. There small table covered by a gingham cloth, a few books (Shakespeare, Gray’s Anatomy), an overflowing ashtray and jar containing a bunch of harebells. The door to the bedr closed. CECILIA is lighting a cigarette as BRIONY advances tentat into the flat. She sees CECILIA’s uniform hanging behind door.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: So you’re a ward sister now?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Yes. CECILIA forces herself to offer BRIONY a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Thanks. BRIONY launches abruptly into what she’s come to say.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I want to go in front of a judge and change my evidence, Cee.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Don’t call me that! She turns away, trying to control herself.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Please don’t ever call me that.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: What I did was terrible, I don’t expect you to forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, I won’t. She turns away again.  83.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: You’re an unreliable witness, they'd never re-open the case.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Well at least I can tell everyone else, I‘ll go home, explain to Mummy and Daddy and...

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: What’s stopping you?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I wanted to see you first.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: They don’t want to know. That unpleasantness is all tidied away in the past, thank you very much. BRIONY starts: the bedroom door has opened and ROBBIE sta front of them, in his uniform shirt and trousers. His shi open revealing a square bandage taped over the wound at h solar plexus. BRIONY is partly obscured from ROBBIE’s vie CECILIA who has turned to him. He talks quietly to CECILI without focusing on BRIONY, then briefly nods in her dire

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Then he’s gone again. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: He sleeps so deeply. BRIONY holds onto the table for support. In silence CECIL begins to move around the kitchen area of the room. She f kettle. Mixes milk and water to egg powder and lays a pot and three plates and cups on the table. Finally they hear click of the bathroom door and ROBBIE whistling as he cro the landing. BRIONY moves as far away from the door as po She’s in his sight line as ROBBIE opens the door. He sees He can’t even address her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: What is she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: She came to speak to me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes? What about?  84.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: The terrible thing I did. ROBBIE moves around the room, putting his hands in his po taking them out again. It’s clear he’s furious, hardly ab contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I’ll be quite honest with you. I’m torn between breaking your neck here and throwing you down the stairs. BRIONY stands her ground, shaken but not afraid.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Have you any idea what it’s like in jail? Course you don’t. Tell me, did it give you pleasure to think of me inside?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: But you did nothing about it.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Do you think I assaulted your cousin?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Did you think it then?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes, yes and no. I wasn’t certain.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: And what’s made you so certain now?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Growing up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Growing up?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I was thirteen.  85.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: How old do you have to be before you know the difference between right and wrong? Do you have to be eighteen before you can own up to a lie? There are soldiers of eighteen old enough to be left to die on the side of the road! Did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Five years ago you didn’t care about telling the truth. You and all your family, you just assumed that for all my education, I was still little better than a servant, still not to be trusted. Thanks to you, they were able to close ranks and throw me to the fucking wolves. BRIONY shakes her head. ROBBIE clenches his fist, looks a might attack her. BRIONY prepares herself, flinching. But CECILIA intervenes, holding on to him, calming him.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Robbie. Robbie, don’t. Please. Look at me, Robbie. Look at me. She kisses him gently and lingeringly on the lips. BRIONY away, something like shame in her eyes. We stay on BRIONY face.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Come back, come back, come back to me. BRIONY looks out of the window. ROBBIE and CECILIA are no talking in low voices as BRIONY watches an OLD WOMAN outs the street below, pushing a pram.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Briony. BRIONY turns.  86.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: There isn’t much time. Robbie has to report for duty at six and he’s got a train to catch. So sit down. There are some things you’re going to do for us. BRIONY and CECILIA sit in the kitchen. ROBBIE leans on th table, looming over them.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You'll go to your parents as soon as you can and tell them everything they need to know to be convinced that your evidence was false. You’1ll go and see a solicitor and make a statement and have it signed and witnessed and send copies to us. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Then you'll write a detailed letter to me, explaining everything that led up to you saying you saw me by the lake.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Try and include whatever you can remember of what Danny Hardman was doing that night.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t Danny Hardman. It was Leon’s friend, Marshall. They both look at her, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: He’s married Lola; I’ve just come from their wedding. Silence. Finally, ROBBIE exhales the breath he’s been hol CECILIA looks across at him.

dialogues.speaker: CECILIA
dialogues.text: Lola won't be able to testify against him now. He’s immune. ROBBIE straightens up and turns away, grappling with a ri emotions. Silence. Finally, BRIONY stands up and speaks,  87. formal.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I’m very, very sorry to have caused you all this terrible distress. I am very, very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Just do what we’ve asked of you. Write it all down.

dialogues.speaker: BRIONY
dialogues.text: I will. I promise. She leaves abruptly, her eyes brimming with tears. EXT. DUDLEY VILLAS. DAY. In the window, CECILIA and ROBBIE are locked in a tender embrace. Below in the street, BRIONY turns away and sets off into distance. INT. UNDERGROUND TRAIN. BRIONY sits on a busy train staring straight ahead, tryin take in all that’s happened, all she’s learnt. Trying not cry. The lights flicker on and off, taking us finally to OVER THIS, the tired VOICE of OLDER BRIONY.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, could we stop for a minute? INT. TV CONTROL ROOM. DAY. 1999. Seen on dozens of monitors, BRIONY TALLIS, 76 now, has interrupted an interview she’s giving for television. Lea forward, she unhooks her radio mike.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Of course. Is anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: I just need a couple of minutes to myself. The VIDEOTAPE rewinds and we’re back to earlier in the interview.  88.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Your new novel, your twenty-first, is called Atonement; it’s a period piece set before and during the Second World War... He breaks off, concerned, as OLDER BRIONY buries her face hands. INT.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Briony? BATHROOM. DAY. Alone, OLDER BRIONY grimaces at her over-made-up face in mirror, pours three aspirin into her hand and washes them Then she lowers her head and closes her eyes. INT. TV STUDIO. DAY. The interview has resumed.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: I'd like to talk now about your new novel, Atonement, which is coming out in a few days to coincide with your birthday. It’s your twenty-first novel... CLOSE on BRIONY, her face against black: where we will re for the rest of her interview.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: It’s my last novel.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Oh, really? You mean you're retiring? OLDER BRIONY contemplates him calmly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: No, dying. Before the INTERVIEWER is quite able to reassemble his th she resumes:

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: My doctor tells me I have something called vascular dementia; which is essentially a continuous series of (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLDER BRIONY (cont'd) tiny strokes. Your brain gradually closes down. You lose words, you lose your memory: which, for a writer, is pretty much the point. That’s why I could finally write this book; and why, of course, it’s my last novel. Strangely enough, it would be just as accurate to call it my first novel. I wrote several drafts as far back as my time at St. Thomas's Hospital during the war. I just couldn’t ever find the way to do it.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Because the novel is autobiographical, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: Yes, entirely. I haven’t changed any names, including my own.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: And was that the problem?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: No. I had for a very long time decided to tell the absolute truth. And I think... She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: You’ve read the book, you’11l understand why. I got first-hand accounts of all the events I didn’t personally witness, conditions in prison, the evacuation of Dunkirk, everything. But the effect of all this honesty was rather...pitiless, you see. I couldn’t any longer imagine what purpose would be served by it.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: By what? By honesty?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: Or reality. Because, in fact, I was too much of a coward to go and see my sister in June, 1940. INT. WATER TOWER AT ST THOMAS’S HOSPITAL. NIGHT. 1940.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIONY sits at her typewriter.  90.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I never made that journey to Balham. So the scene in which I confess to them is invented, imagined. INT. CECILIA’S FLAT IN BALHAM. DAY. ROBBIE’s face; the empty bed.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And, in fact, could never have happened... INT. CELLAR AT BRAY DUNES. DAWN. CORPORAL NETTLE removes a piece of wood from the entrance bombed out cellar. Light pours in.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-because Robbie Turner died of septicaemia at Bray Dunes on the first of June 1940, the last day of the evacuation... ROBBIE lies dead amongst the rubble; beside him is the bu letters and CECILIA’s photograph. NETTLE picks up the let

dialogues.speaker: NETTLE
dialogues.text: Cheerio, pal. He covers ROBBIE’s face and puts the letters in his pocke INT. PLATFORM ON BALHAM TUBE STATION. NIGHT. A thick pipe, running above the platform, is dripping, undramatic but regular.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. and I was never able to put things right with my sister Cecilia... A WIDE SHOT shows the platform, dimly lit, crowded with s bodies, mostly women and children. PAN OVER the bodies: one of them, CECILIA, as it turns ou opens her eyes, quite calmly, at the SOUND of muffled exp from the first bombs falling on the street above. The lig flicker and revive.  gl. EXT. BALHAM TUBE STATION. NIGHT. The illuminated sign above the station also flickers and out. Out here the SOUND and flash of the bombs is far mor present.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-because she was killed on the 15th of October, 1940... INT. BALHAM TUBE STATION. NIGHT. A vast wall of water cascades, in slow motion, down the d escalators.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...by the bomb that destroyed the gas and water mains above Balham tube station. INT. PLATFORM ON BALHAM TUBE STATION. NIGHT. CECILIA sits up as the lights flicker and, this time, go The thunderous roar of the approaching waters. INT. UNDERWATER. CECILIA’s body, balletically graceful, hair fantailed out drifts through the tube tunnel towards a distant light. INT. T.V. STUDIO. DAY. 1999. OLDER BRIONY looks intently at the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: So my sister and Robbie never had the time together they both so longed for and deserved, which, ever since, I’'ve...always felt I prevented. But what sense of hope or satisfaction could a reader derive from an ending like that? So, in the book, I wanted to give Robbie and Cecilia what they (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLDER BRIONY (cont'd) lost out on in life. I’d like to think this wasn’t weakness or evasion, but a final act of kindness. She thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER BRIONY
dialogues.text: I gave them their happiness. EXT. BEACH BELOW WHITE CLIFFS. DAY. ROBBIE and CECILIA crunch across the pebbles and splash gleefully through the waves, below the towering white cli their way back to their white clapboard cottage.
